awd_titl_txt: Spanning Boundaries: A Statewide Network to Support Science Teacher Leaders to Implement Science Standards
awd_abstract_narration:
Current priorities in school science education include building strong professional learning communities that foster ongoing professional growth among teachers, teacher leaders, and school administrators. This project responds to these priorities by developing and testing a two-year professional development model for secondary school science teacher leaders that will help them support their colleagues in implementing the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS). The new model for professional learning combines three key elements: 1) Focusing on teacher leaders who can interpret, translate, and incorporate new approaches and resources into local contexts, 2) Engaging the expertise of informal science education specialists who are well versed in teacher professional learning and experiential approaches to learning, and 3) Establishing a statewide network of peers who can share experiences beyond individual school and district contexts. By developing a geographically-distributed network of support for science teacher leaders, the project is poised to create more equitable access to high quality professional learning opportunities for teachers as well as provide much needed support to the disproportionate number of novice teachers in schools with high populations of historically underrepresented students in science. 

This early stage design and development project is guided by two research questions: 1) How do teacher leaders utilize structures, practices, and tools within an informal science institution-based network to interpret, filter, and translate available resources into professional learning supports for localized implementation of phenomena-based instruction? And 2) How do the professional learning supports developed by teacher leaders become more aligned with best practices for professional development (e.g., active learning, sustained, coherent, collaborative, and content-based) and incorporate aspects of informal learning (e.g., choice and experiential learning) throughout their participation in an ISI-based network? The project will engage two cohorts of 25 middle and high school science teacher leaders in overlapping two-year, one-week summer institutes, and a minimum of 12 online meetings during the academic years. The 30-hour summer institutes will be designed to address the multiple roles of teacher leaders as learners, classroom teachers, and teacher professional development providers. To sustain professional development across the academic year, monthly two-hour online meetings will be used to nurture the community of practice. Some sessions will focus on leadership and topics related to the NGSS, and other sessions will focus on deepening science content knowledge. The sources of data to be used in addressing the research questions include: 1) Video recordings, field notes of observations, and artifacts of professional development meetings, 2) Interviews with teacher leaders, and 3) Journal entries and artifacts from professional development sessions implemented by teacher leaders.   

The Discovery Research preK-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers, through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools. Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project implemented a professional learning program for science teacher leaders (STLs) to support implementation of science standards in California and studied how STLs interpret, filter, and translate available resources into local professional learning supports for phenomena-based instruction. The program was provided within the context of a statewide network of STLs created by the Exploratorium, an informal science institution (ISI) in San Francisco. The project also studied how combining best practices for professional development with features of informal learning could support STLs' professional learning and how an ISI is positioned to support such a network.

Thirty-six STLs participated in two one-year cohorts, with 20 participating in both years. Programming took place between fall 2020 and spring 2022 and was deeply impacted by the covid-19 pandemic and the immediate needs of STLs during this time. Each cohort was divided into five communities of practice (CoPs) that met monthly online throughout the academic year, with a final in-person celebration at the end of the project. Implementation of NGSS remained a focus for science teachers and teacher leaders in California, and each CoP determined a specific problem of practice that addressed their immediate local needs in providing phenomena-based science learning during the pandemic. Group topics included implementing hands-on activities remotely, equitable teaching practices, understanding antiracism and culturally responsive teaching in science, and developing anchoring phenomena. 

STLs worked in a wide range of urban, suburban, and rural settings across California and held a variety of formal positions, including participants who were primarily classroom teachers to those working in district and county education offices. Despite this range of contexts, we identified seven roles that STLs occupy in their leadership practice: activist, ambassador, collaborator, innovator, networker, organizer, and translator. These roles helped researchers and participants articulate different areas of strength and growth in their science teacher leadership, acknowledging and broadening the ways teacher leaders are defined and identified. 

Across these leadership roles, STLs must interact with several actors within the education system to identify knowledge and practice gaps related to science education improvement in their context. To attend to these gaps, STLs use their networks to locate, interpret, filter, and translate resources for the teachers with whom they work. The CoP structure for professional learning supported these boundary spanning activities of STLs by providing interactions with like-minded peers who face similar challenges and successes. CoPs offered a space to reduce isolation, facilitate resource sharing, and understand different perspectives. Structures that supported boundary spanning included collectively defining a problem of practice, mapping the network of actors in one's leadership context, modeled pedagogy of science activities and talking protocols, and time to work together on resource development. These structures are grounded in best practices for professional development while incorporating aspects of informal learning such as choice, experiential learning, and joy. Interviews and artifacts showed that STLs experienced immediate value in the CoPs, and they gained knowledge, practices, and resources that supported their specific work in their context. All participants were able to articulate new perspectives and structures for science teacher learning in their leadership work. Learn how STLs think about different aspects of science teacher leadership by viewing the videos at www.exploratorium.edu/education/teacher-institute/listening-science-teacher-leaders.

There are a number of organizations in California that support science teachers and leaders, and the project also conducted a landscape study to see how the Exploratorium, as an informal science institution, fits within this landscape. The Exploratorium was in the second highest quartile in terms of teacher served and listed as a top collaborator by several of the organizations who serve the highest number of teachers. The size of the institution positions it well to have deep connections with individual STLs (such as through facilitating CoPs), while having a scalable reach through collaborators and a growing network of STLs. The ISI sits adjacent to the formal science education system and provides a venue for non-evaluative connections and support between professionals with similar roles in different contexts. A social network analysis of participants show that their feelings of inclusion and identification with the CoPs and the statewide network were very high and that they highly rate the resources they gained through the program. Notably, the analysis showed there were connections made between participants across CoP groups, demonstrating the impact of the network beyond specifically designated programming. We will continue to grow and study the statewide network as a platform for implementing reform, and this structure could serve as a model for ISIs who serve science teachers in other states.
